body: @saileshmittal - Can you incorporate the feedback from @billonahill and merge this in?

:+1: @saileshmittal if that version works for tracker, but please verify both travis CI and twitter CI integration tests pass.
@billonahill Unfortunately, we don't have integration tests for tracker and UI, but I have verified that it works internally.
@supunkamburugamuve - thanks. I was wondering if you add some documentation for Slurm. It will be nice. I will request @maosongfu to take a look at this.
Had cleaned up local machine states and the master worked. Closing this PR since it is not required.
@joestein Hi I still could not open page https://github.com/elodina/heron; I don't think I have the permission yet.
@maosongfu I add you maybe email invite didn't go through you should see it here https://github.com/elodina then accept should get you in
Confirmed with Twitter Messaging team. They are happy to contribute the DistributedLog spout.
@joestein Thanks I can access now. Will review it today.

This PR mentions a very good problem, but the solution may not work. We rely on Zookeeper for leader election to void multiple Scheduler running as master at the same time; and a Scheduler exits when failing to set SchedulerLocation on zookeeper.

This PR will cause: once a Scheduler fails unexpectedly, then no any new scheduler can start again. (Fails to set Scheduler Location on zookeeper since it is not permanent and not cleaned by any one.)

Let's discuss and figure out a more complete and sound solution.

If the scheduler is a long running service, setting the location as ephemeral node is totally fine and can avoid multiple scheduler running as master problem. 

But in our Aurora Scheduler case, it's not a long running service.  Thus we are not setting the scheduler location at all. We should find some way to persist the location in this case in order for tracker/ui get it.
Handled in PR #678 using a submodule
@saileshmittal are we blocked on anything else for this? If this changes requires some manual re-basing step we should do it this week.
No blocked. I will test it today, and if all goes well, I will send an email on mailing list to notify everyone and do it about two hours after that, or may be after 24 hours.
@lucperkins made one more tweak to `Makefile` to make localhost links resolve better. Without `--server` links were kicking me out to github.
@kramasamy these does either still need to be added, or the pages that references them needs to not do so.
Can u also add unit tests?

+1

One thing to be a bit wary of in the future is letting the line length grow well beyond 80 characters. At some point we should go through and make sure that this is standardized, but we can slay that dragon another day.
@maosongfu sure, I'll add the unit test once other updates are finished

Hi @joestein I reviewed the code and I noticed that the mesos scheduler is on top of a pretty old version of heron scheduler spi, for instance, the schedulers location (currently they are under heron/schedulers/...); and the IScheduler interface, for instance, no more onActivate() or onHealthCheck(). Is it feasible that you refactor it to align with latest scheduler spi?

Thanks.
a small example can be found [here](https://github.com/yallop/popl2015-papers)

Another approach we could consider would be changing the Java style checker in CI so it could run once over all files in the repo and disabling the compile-triggered checker. We'd still want the latter for developer compiling target that they're working on. We could probably do this with an new option to say not to use the `extra_action_file` to get the class list, but to instead take a find expression.

https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/tools/java/src/com/twitter/bazel/checkstyle/JavaCheckstyle.java#L51
We keep the committers since they can contribute even if they are not it twitter.
@maosongfu Thanks for the feedback. Did most of the improvements suggested. Need to test with the localzk.

Hi @supunkamburugamuve 
I have just merged pull request: #706 , and now you can use SchedulerUtils.setupWorkingDirectory(...) as an utils method; no longer duplicated code in Launcher/Scheduler.
@maosongfu thanks, moved the code to new methods and tested with zk.
Handing it off to @joestein since he is updating the Mesos Scheduler along with Vagrant.
Need we add other similar classes, for instance, some test bolts, from storm too?
@maosongfu We can add them later when needed.
I further cleaned other unused or missing import for all the cli files

Good call @lucperkins done.

Also added a link to the linkchecker issue:
https://github.com/wummel/linkchecker/pull/657

#715 has merged. Now accessing:
Runtime.instanceDistribution(runtime)
Runtime.numContainers(runtime);
can get appropriate values, rather than NPE.
Probably local scheduler implementation could be a good place to start.

üëç 

Why can we not merge this until the warnings are fixed? We have warnings currently right, and we ignore them?
#690 was auto-closed by the git history cleanup and never submitted. #709 actually included the fix, but the check is currently disabled until #346 is done and the bad links are fixed.
@nlu90 once the links above have pages and work, please enable the CI link checker with the one liner change discussed in .travis.yml in #709.
Please merge from master and verify again that Travis CI works with these changes. I just merges the linkcheck travis CI work to master.
I think this can be closed now

We should open another ticket to track getting this enabled, or re-open this one:
https://github.com/twitter/heron/blob/master/website/javadocs.sh#L5
one can turn on `set -e` since `javadoc.sh` exits with `0` now. This means Travis CI test won't fail on `make site`

@kramasamy @billonahill docker image upgraded to heron v.0.13.7, launches UI automatically. docker hub repos "heron" "heronstream" "heronstreaming" reserved. 

step 1: launch docker terminal, check and save local docker-machine ip address
$ docker-machine ip default
for example: 192.168.99.100

step 2: pull and launch docker image with /bin/bash , specify port address with -p
docker run -it -p 8888:8888 -p 8889:8889 puffin:u14.04h0.13.7 /bin/bash
this maps tracker port :8888-> {your-docker-ip}:8888 and ui :8889 -> {your-docker-ip}:8889

step 3: within container, submit heron example (following getting-started guide)
heron submit local ~/.heron/examples/heron-examples.jar com.twitter.heron.examples.ExclamationTopology ExclamationTopology

step 4: check running topology UI on local machine
http://{your-docker-ip}:8889
example: http://192.168.99.100:8889/

currently heron-tracker and heron-ui run in background and output to command line. this can be cleaned up to output to file if desired.
